one_sentence_definition: A permissionless on-chain marketplace for swapping tokens and providing liquidity using smart contracts rather than centralized order books.
A liquidity protocol that prices trades algorithmically using on-chain pools and bonding curves instead of matching individual buy/sell orders.
An AMM approach that allows liquidity providers to allocate capital within custom price ranges to increase capital efficiency.
An on-chain shared order book model where limit orders are aggregated and matched to provide low-latency, order-book style trading.
Protocols and markets for margin, perpetual futures, options, and other derivative products that enable leveraged positions and hedging on-chain.
Services that source liquidity and compute optimal multi-path routing across multiple pools or DEXs to minimise slippage and fees.
Automated vault strategies that aggregate capital and optimize yield by compositing protocols, auto-compounding returns, and rebalancing positions.
Smart-contract driven markets that enable deposits to earn yield and allow over-collateralized or algorithmic borrowing against on-chain assets.
Tokenized representations of staked assets that let users retain liquidity (tradable tokens) while their underlying tokens are staked to securing a chain.
Mechanisms that re-use staked assets (or BTC) to secure additional protocols or create yield, increasing on-chain liquidity for proof assets like BTC.
The process and protocols for representing physical or off-chain assets (e.g., real estate, gold, invoices) as on-chain tokens and creating financial products around them.
Mechanisms and systems for issuing and maintaining stable-value tokens, often via collateralized debt positions (CDPs) and liquidation/peg-stabilization logic.
Services that securely ingest and publish off-chain data (e.g., prices, events, randomness) onto blockchains for smart contract consumption.
Protocols and tools that move assets, messages, or state between different blockchains, enabling multi-chain composability.
Distributed storage networks and data-availability layers designed to persist large or arbitrary data off-chain while ensuring retrievability and censorship resistance.
Multi-Party Computation-based protocols for distributed private-key custody, enabling threshold signatures, keyless wallets, and low-trust signing.
Multi-signature smart-contract wallets and governance-controlled treasury tools for secure, shared control of funds and on-chain operations.
On-chain naming and identity systems that map human-readable identifiers to wallets, metadata, and decentralized identifiers for improved UX and anti-Sybil uses.
Identity systems using privacy-preserving cryptography (e.g., ZK proofs) to enable anonymous KYC, Sybil-resistance, and selective disclosure without exposing raw data.
ZK-based protocols and verification layers that enable succinct, privacy-preserving proofs and off-chain computation verification for on-chain use.
Libraries, SDKs, APIs, and open-source toolchains that accelerate building, integrating, and deploying smart contracts and dApps on-chain.
The Move language and associated tooling/ecosystem used to author and deploy smart contracts on Move-based chains (e.g., Sui, Aptos).
Design patterns for token incentives including vote-escrow (ve) mechanics, emission schedules, buybacks, staking rewards, and community incentives.
Advanced AMM designs (e.g., dynamic fees, bonding curves, multiple AMM engines) that adapt parameters for capital efficiency and price discovery.
Atomic borrowing primitives that allow uncollateralized loans within a single transaction, enabling arbitrage, liquidation, and composability patterns.
Blockchain-native AI services and agent frameworks that coordinate identity, continuity, and consensus for autonomous or semi-autonomous on-chain agents and models.
Tools and protocols that index, analyze, and surface actionable insights from on-chain wallet activity and transaction data for users and dApps.

keyword: P2P Marketplaces & Smart Escrow for Game Assets
one_sentence_definition: Peer-to-peer trading platforms for game items, accounts, and in-game assets that use smart-contract escrow or multisig to secure trades and settlements.
Integrated gaming platforms that combine blockchain-native assets, play-to-earn mechanics, metaverse land/avatars, and token-driven economies.
Marketplaces and protocols for minting, trading, fractionalizing and managing provenance/ownership of digital collectibles and tokenized assets.

keyword: Decentralized Advertising Exchanges & Web3 Ad Economies
one_sentence_definition: Blockchain-native marketplaces and economic models for buying/selling ad inventory and rewarding users/publishers with on-chain incentives.
Protocols that let users take directional or hedged positions on yield-bearing instruments, swap yield exposure, or synthetically long/short yields.
Managed vaults and strategy containers that run market-making, hedging or other automated strategies to generate returns for depositors.
Cryptographic randomness services (e.g., VRF) that provide verifiable, tamper-resistant random numbers for gaming, lotteries, and fair contract logic.
Practices, tooling and protocols for auditing, securing smart contracts, managing treasury risk, liquidation logic, and operational security.
Protocols and designs that make assets or native chain value usable across ecosystems without relying solely on wrapped tokens or trust-heavy bridges.
Duplicate placeholder (not used).
Decentralized Physical Infrastructure Networks that tokenise access, ownership, or utility of real-world devices and networks for Web3 services.
Layer-2 architectures (rollups, optimistic/zk) and custom scaling chains designed to increase throughput and reduce gas costs for a base layer.
Blockchain-native casino and betting mechanics (e.g., roulette, dice, coinflip) that leverage provable randomness and trustless settlement.
